posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked: Hey guys, We have a problem where even though we have all our feed forward constants set to zero and we run a pure profiled pid, the elevator creeps upwards slowly even after the pid reaches the set point. If the elevator was drifting downwards, I would understand it might be due to gravity but I don’t see anything that might cause it to drift upwards. I will share the code once I get a chance to push it to GitHub but does anyone ha e any suggestions?

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked: Is your elevator sprung? (Aka does it have springs helping it up?)

posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked: No, we have a chain and sprocket moving the elevator

posts.name: Jason Johnson
posts.cooked:
Do you have a vg term to apply voltage to the elevator?  If it is too high it will continue to rise.

Also, have you tried turning down the P in the PID .  Do you have any term for I?

posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked: I set the g constant to 0 after noticing the drift. The drift upwards gets noticeably better the lower the p, but the elevator also takes longer to reach set point. We have our I term at 0 for now

posts.name: Jason Johnson
posts.cooked: The WPILIB documentation has steps to tune the elevator.  We started by increasing vg until the point it started to rise.  They we dialed it back by 20%.  We then turned attention to the P term.  We set them told the elevator to goto a position.  We kept turning up until it reached the value.  We did not use any I or D terms

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
Do you have a defaultCommand that applies an output that would stop it? This could be a literal motor.stopmotor() , a motor.setReference(..) , or a motor.set(feedforward.calculate)

Depending on the exact way you generate the output (notably a  profiledPID entirely on the rio), the final set() or setVoltage() would stick after the command ends. It’s likely this is not a zero value, and can be high enough that the motor just continues to apply this value until something else steps in to change it.

posts.name: Jason Johnson
posts.cooked:
Here is the link to our source code.  We increased the speed by modifying the velocity and acceleration constants afte the PID was working.

The values will differ based upon the weight of your elevator, gearbox, and types of motors

Reefscape robot for team 6239. Contribute to frc6239/compbot-2025 development by creating an account on GitHub.

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked: Weird question but is the encoder value also increasing? As in, does the robot know the elevator is drifting upwards or does it for some reason think it’s stationary at a height just below the setpoint and applying a low voltage to try and reach that last inch and not detecting the slow movement.

posts.name: Ryan zheng
posts.cooked: @tekdemo We have a default command that resets the elevator to the zero position when our scoring button isn’t being held down. That does makes sense, I will make sure to pass a command to stop the motor when it reaches the setpoint. @bathtubed Yes, the robot’s positional encoder we use to control the elevator pid knows the position is changing . @jsjohn2000 @Oblarg Thanks for linking the vertical elevator tutorial and providing some example code. I think I’m gonna try retuning the elevator from scratch when I get the scratch to rule out any mistakes in that tuning process.

posts.name: Kirby Caldwell
posts.cooked:
An easier way of making set states on an elevator without using PID would be setting up a “bang bang” controller. This should prevent any potential creeping problems and get very consistent set states.

‘’‘public Command goTo(double rotations) { return defer(()->{ if(getHeight() < rotations) return run(()->runClimber(Constants.ClimberConstants.CLIMBER_SPEED_UP)) .until(()->getHeight() > rotations) .andThen(new InstantCommand(() → runClimber(Constants.ClimberConstants.CLIMBER_HOLD_UP))); else if(getHeight() > rotations) return run(()->runClimber(Constants.ClimberConstants.CLIMBER_SPEED_DOWN)).until(()->getHeight() < rotations); // .andThen(new InstantCommand(() → //runClimber(Constants.ClimberConstants.CLIMBER_HOLD_UP)));; return run(()->runClimber(0)); }); }    ‘’’

This is how you set a bang bang controller up. (of course without the triple ticks). In my experience this is more stable and consistent than PID especially when working with a heavier elevator. Here is an example of how you would use the unit “rotations” which is the internal primary encoder for NEO 500’s. (you can substitute this if you have an external absolute encoder.)

‘’’ //Set State for L1 m_operatorController.cross().onTrue(m_climber.goTo(1)); //Set State for L2 m_operatorController.square().onTrue(m_climber.goTo(4)); //Set State for L3 m_operatorController.triangle().onTrue(m_climber.goTo(10)); //Set State for L4 m_operatorController.circle().onTrue(m_climber.goTo(22)); //Set State for Barge m_operatorController.touchpad().onTrue(m_climber.goTo(25.5)); ‘’’

This will cause you to stop perfectly when you reach the desired rate. (There is a very small margin of error that can be accounted for when you are reading the “rotation” values) The way I have this code set up, once it goes up it will stay up, and in order to go any further up you have to go down to zero so the CLIMBER_HOLD_UP speed isn’t running anymore. You can of course replace CLIMBER_SPEED_UP/DOWN with whatever constants you have. If you have any questions please let me know! I know a bang bang controller probably isn’t the solution you were looking for, but it could be completely functional instead of struggling with this PID issue.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked: I would hesitate to recommend a bang bang controller for this application. Those are typically useful only when the system’s output is constrained to binary or tertiary values (on/off or on/off/reverse). The physical stability and basic functionality of a bang bang relies significantly on system being relatively unresponsive to major swings in output, such as an elevator/arm being extremely torqued down. This is unlikely to be the case for most robots. For these systems with lighter gearing… a badly set up bang bang is likely to cause serious damage. Even in a best case, a well tuned bang-bang is going to be strictly worse than a poorly tuned P control system.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
If you’re still struggling, I’d suggest finding a way to link your code (preferably a github), so folks can review what you’re telling the bot to do. If you have a lot of the basic tuning stuff handled, it’s entirely possible you have a logic error somewhere.

Also, just to double check (because I’ve seen this a couple times recently): You’re not using Revs ff or velocityFF gain on a Spark PID when using position SetReference(), correct? This parameter can be handy for velocity systems, but on positional ones, it just multiplies the setpoint (height) times a gain, meaning the higher the system is, the higher the output.

posts.name: Kirby Caldwell
posts.cooked: I suggested it purely if they needed a last resort option. I haven’t had a chance to look at their robot’s actual code so I could only give general advice on their PID .

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked:
We had a similar issue due to a really high acceleration causing a sprocket to skip in relation to our chain. What we ended up doing was letting our voltage ramp up over time instead of going immediately to max voltage. Every time the elevator receives a new target height, it starts a timer, and our voltage is clamped by the value of the timer times a constant to prevent us from having that issue. Another way to solve this would be to implement a profiled pid controller that allows you to set a max acceleration and velocity.

On top of that, once your elevator has already skipped, it’s possible to check and correct for that. What we do is check to see if we’re applying a downward voltage for ~1 second, and the elevator refuses to move; that tells us that we’ve probably skipped somewhere along the way, and it’s a good time to reset our encoder reading to 0.
